awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Piezoelectric sensor for in-situ strength monitoring of infrastructure materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of sensing technology to accurately monitor infrastructure conditions in real time.  U.S. infrastructure has been deteriorating: Of 6 million bridges in the United States, 13.6% are obsolete, 9% are structurally deficient, and 39% have exceeded their designed lifetimes. The worldwide market for structural monitoring is estimated to increase to $3.4 billion in 2023 from $1.5 billion in 2018 at a compound annual growth rate of 17.9%. Development of cost-effective and user-friendly sensing technologies is important for construction, maintenance, and rehabilitation to monitor concrete strength and evaluate infrastructure condition.  The proposed technology may mitigate premature failure and reduce infrastructure construction/maintenance costs, save the time of construction workers and commuters, ensure safety by limiting in-field operations, and enabling data-driven infrastructure-related decisions.  This may help to ensure the safety of commuters/travelers and construction workers and reduce expenditures on infrastructure construction and maintenance.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a wireless sensing technology for real-time concrete strength monitoring. In-situ and real-time monitoring of construction materials, such as concrete, is crucial to the safety and security of our nation’s infrastructure. However, available non-destructive techniques typically measure concrete temperature and refer to a database of strength versus temperature information developed in lab settings for a specific concrete mix to determine the strength. In contrast, the newly developed technology enables direct measurement of in-situ strength of concrete in real-time. Benefits include high accuracy, fast response, no need of data-base calibration, significantly reduced cost, and ease of implementation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF I-Corps team project is built upon the discovery and technology innovation on a real-time IoT sensing platform for infrastructure monitoring. The PI and her research team have filled multiple knowledge gaps in technology transition of the IoT sensors for infrastructure monitoring, including value proposition; customer/user-case; demand creation; channel development; revenue model; partnership strategy; and resource development. A thorough study of the market and related paths to commercialization was performed. Customer segments and value propositions along with beachhead market were identified through 120 interviews and a business model canvas model was built. Learnings from the NSF I-Corps strengthened the commercialization potential of technology and accelerated its way towards commercialization. The PI and her team have filed two international patent applications, and established a startup company, Wavelogix Inc. to commercialize the technology. The company has raised $500K pre-seed funding, hired one full-time CEO, three full-time engineers, and submitted one NSF Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) grant. 

       The technology addresses significant infrastructure-related problems. Out of about 6 million bridges in the United States, 42% are over 50 years old and 7.5% are structurally deficient. Length of bridges equivalent to over 6300 miles need repairs. An estimated expense for such repair is 170 billion dollars per year. Delays in construction schedules in vertical infrastructure due to insufficient information about the concrete strength results in losses of millions of dollars every year. Moreover, structurally deficient infrastructure can cause catastrophic failures and even cost lives (for eg. collapse of the Surfside condo in Florida on June 24, 2021resulted in 98 deaths and 11 injuries). Worldwide market for structural health monitoring is estimated to increase to 3.4 billion dollars in 2023 from 1.5 billion dollars at a compound annual growth rate of 17.9%. Development of cost-effective and user-friendly techniques to quickly and accurately monitor concrete strength and evaluate infrastructure condition is of utmost importance for construction, maintenance, and rehabilitations; these needs will be met using the proposed technology.

       Furthermore, this program has provided training opportunities for the PI and her postdoc and PhD students at the Purdue University to develop skillset in entrepreneurship and technology transfer. These skills could help the researchers commercializing their future inventions. The PI and her team also involve in providing research experience for undergraduate students and k-12 students working as summer intern at PI?s laboratory at Purdue University. The research team has also disseminated their I-Corps experience and ?Lean LaunchPad method? to local and regional business community through multiple business venues, including Purdue Foundry, Purdue Research Foundations, and Woman in STEM leadership conference etc. 

 


Last Modified: 08/11/2022
Modified by: Na (Luna) Lu
